funFacts: Aramaic has been in continuous use for over 3,000 years—few languages can claim such longevity.
‘Abba’, ‘Talitha kum’, and ‘Eli, Eli lama sabachthani’ in the New Testament are preserved Aramaic phrases.
Modern Neo-Aramaic is still spoken in villages of northern Iraq, Syria, Iran, and by diaspora communities in Chicago and Stockholm.
The Aramaic alphabet eventually evolved into both the Hebrew ‘square’ script and the Nabataean script, ancestor of Arabic letters.
A few scenes in Mel Gibson’s film ‘The Passion of the Christ’ revived popular interest in learning Aramaic.
